tackle.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to try to deal with a difficult problem
tackle.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: There is more than one way to tackle the problem.
It took twelve fire engines to tackle the blaze.
tackle.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to try to take the ball away from an opponent in a game such as football or hockey
tackle.translation[0].definitions[2].def: to force someone to the ground so that they stop running, in a game such as American football or rugby
tackle.translation[0].definitions[3].def: to talk to someone in order to deal with a difficult problem
tackle.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: When I tackled Susan about it, she admitted she’d made a mistake.
tackle.translation[0].definitions[4].def: to start fighting someone, especially a criminal
tackle.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: I certainly couldn’t tackle both of them on my own.
tackle.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: The government has failed to tackle the problem of youth crime.
She said she couldn’t face tackling the job on her own.
Fire crews tackling the blaze were hampered by exploding gas canisters.
The police set up a special task force to tackle street crime in the capital.
He believes education is the long-term key to tackling poverty.
The government announced a new initiative to tackle unemployment.
The issue of cost must be tackled head-on.
tackle.translation[1].definitions[0].def: an attempt to take the ball from an opponent in a game such as football
tackle.translation[1].definitions[1].def: an attempt to stop an opponent by forcing them to the ground, especially in American football or rugby
tackle.translation[1].definitions[2].def: a player in American football who stops other players by tackling them or preventing them from moving forward
tackle.translation[1].definitions[3].def: the equipment used in some sports and activities, especially fishing
tackle.translation[1].definitions[4].def: ropes and pulleys (=wheels) used for lifting heavy things
